conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand how the position and size of the shadows (A, B, C, and D) change when the light source moves downward.
Object A is a small, light-colored object (possibly a figurine).
Object B is a black object with a floral pattern.
Object C is a red object (possibly a cake or a similar item).
Object D is a roll of tape.
Shadow A is cast by Object A.
Shadow B is cast by Object B.
Shadow C is cast by Object C.

When the light source moves downward, the angle at which the light hits the objects will change. This will affect the direction and length of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves downward, the shadows will generally become longer and more spread out because the angle of incidence will increase, causing the shadows to extend further from the objects.
conclusion: The shadows will become longer and move further away from their respective objects.
